subject: Re: what you hear is what you get
author: James W. Hyslope
full_text:
Wasn't scary...actually was very good :) It definitely DIDN'T deserve the low box office rating IMOHA. Worked off the theme "National Treasure". I tried to watch the first one "Da Vinci Code", but it seemed to involved (had to stay alert into the plot) so I shut er down :)--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, SnowfireL@... wrote:

> (mailto:EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com) ,  "April Abercrombie" <april@> wrote:
> > > >
> > > >  Thanks Jim! IMO, that is the biggest problem that serious 
> researchers of any  field face-their own biases. It is good to be skeptical, but you 
> HAVE to keep  open to any possibility, and realize that there can be holes in 
> even your own,  well thought out theories. Once you think you know it all 
> and don't need to  test further, you are lost.
> > > > 
> > > > I have  several pairs of headphones, but my best pair are Sennheiser 
> eH 150's. I don't  truly know a whole lot about headphones, I only know 
> these came highly  recommended and were moderately priced. I think I paid $50. 
> They are very  light and comfortable for full headphones. They have thick, 
> padded ear cuffs  and a padded headband. The others I have-the ear bud types, 
> make my ears hurt.  On investigations I use them for live monitoring, so I 
> wear them for long  periods of time.
> > > >

> > > > > Yes April, I have the same  belief as you.....if EVP's are of the 
> personal nature, no matter if they yell  into the microphone.. Yes April, I 
> have the same  belief as you.....if EVP's are of the personal nature, no 
> matter if they yell  into the microphone..<WBR>..if you are not the intended 
> receiver you will  NEVER hear or understand it. I do know my EVP's are very LOW 
> audio. I need to  work with that and AMP them I guess. In some recordings 
> (1927 is one of them)  I can't hear the voice sometimes, that is how low it 
> is. But tonight I  finished my comparison recorder evaluations (ran 3 
> recorders that night) my  Sony ICD B7 also heard the date. The Panasonic RR-US360 
> could not hear it. I  will upload a GET-OUT evp that the RR-DR60 only heard 
> too. Was recorded same  time as the asking of date.As for "what kind of ears 
> I have" :) I do have  pretty good hearing (but have some loss in certain 
> areas) maybe my losses are  closer to the static's level and I am helped 
> there....I don't know yet. I have  seen enough people (half) that I personally let 
> hear these....they can't hear  them either (s_EVP-ITC@yahoogroupsEVP-_

> > > > > > I always listen to EVP wiht my ears!--I  know--alien humor.
> > > > > > 
> > > > > > On  Fri, May 15, 2009 at 1:24 PM, April Abercrombie <april@> 
> wrote:
> >  > > > > 
> > > > > > 
> > > > > >  I always listen to EVP's with high quality headphones. In the 
> "tomorrow let  you know" EVP, I do hear something...  I always listen to EVP's 
> with high quality headphones. In the "tomorrow let  you know" EVP, I do 
> hear something...<WBR>.just can't be sure that it is a  voi  I always listen to 
> EVP's with high quality headphones. In the "tomorrow let  you know" EVP, I 
> do hear something...<WBR>.just can't be sure that it is a  voice. I does 
> have a cadence similar to someone speaking, but it could just as  easily be 
> something present in the environment-<WBR>a natural background  noise. There is 
> no way for me to tell for certain as it is just too feint. I  can't make 
> out any clear words. Sure-I could probably matrix some in, but that  is all it 
> would be. For an EVP to be considered proof positive of spirit  
> communication by the community at large, it has to be clear enough that many  people 
> hear the same thing, without hints or coaxing. If you have to have high  
> quality devices to make it out, it just isn't good enough. That does not mean  it 
> isn't a true EVP, just that it isn't good enough to stand as evidence. As  
> for the whistle, it sounded like feedback to me as well, but I will have to  
> take you word for it that you were no where near any other electronics or  
> EMF's that could contribute to feedback. Even so, if I am trying to remain  
> unbiased and objective, there is no way for me to say this is a spirit,  
> without personally being with you when you caught it. The only thing I can  
> still say about it is could be, but for me it is non conclusive. If someone  
> does not hear what you are hearing, try to remain objective and just  
> understand that it isn't personal. You have to understand that with just these  
> recordings alone, there is no way to scientifically prove what you have  
> recorded is spirit communication. If you could get consistent, intelligent  
> question and answer recordings, then you would be alot closer. Here again, we  are 
> back to the "So what?" thing. You don't HAVE to prove anything  
> scientifically, unless you want others to completely believe in your 
> ev_EVP-ITC@yahoogroupsEVP-_ (mailto:EVP-ITC@...m)  Sent:  Friday, May 15, 2009 12:02 
> PMSubject: [EVP-ITC] Re: what you hear is what you  get
> > > > > > Okay, I can respect that. If you can't hear  them then it must be 
> either mechanical (sound card or headphones)or maybe your  hearing has loss 
> in those frequencies. Okay, I can respect that. If you can't hear  them 
> then it must be either mechanical (sound card or headph&  your headphones. I 
> have let an older man listen (in his late 60's) and he has  heard most all of 
> the audio. Same with a few guys at work. Some hear them  right away, and 
> others can't until I loop the actually EVP for a few tries. I  personally use a 
> Dell Latitude D430 to hear these. I can hear some on my cell  phone. 
> Headphones are a must....or you won't hear anything either way. *But  some can be 
> heard on cell phone without headphones. The conversion to MP3 has  also 
> caused some loss, but I am still able to hear them when I review from  this site 
> (but I have the repetive hearing syndrome in this area no doubt).  Although 
> I do have some disbelief (shock) that a few of these are not  discernable. 
> Go back and listen to "tomorrow let you know" is in a  gruffy-robotic 
> melodic tone at the very end but with higher natural volume.  And if you couldn't 
> hear the whistle...I would suggest the need to remove the  cotton from the 
> ear :) As for feedback....  your headphones. I have let an older man listen 
> (in his late 60's) and he has  heard most all of the audio. Same with a few 
> guys at work. Some hear them  right away, and others can't until I loop the 
> actually EVP for a few tries. I  personally use a Dell Latitude D430 to hear 
> these. I can hear some on my cell  phone. Headphones are a must....or you 
> won't hear anything either way. *But  s_EVP-ITC@yahoogroupsEVP-_

> > > >  > > > 
> > > > > > > If EVP messages are for the  one that recorded them, then it

> not give people the chance to  critique.
> > > > > > > 
> > > > > > >  Now I could see if someone flat out said your recordings were 
> all trash,  period. You would have every right to be angry, but no one is 
> saying that, at  least I am not saying that.
> > > > > > > 
> > >  > > > > I just stated that I did not hear what James heard, and  
> though I wasn't going to say he doesn't have anything, I can't say that he  does 
> either.

> > > > > > > 
> >  > > > > > So my suggestion to you, if you want to get less  subjective 
> conjuctures or simply less affirmations of your own  interpretations, is to 
> post the future ones without labels. The labels you  give can influence the 
> listeners: when you have a sound that could be several  things, and you note 
> that it sounded like "keep it moving", the listener can  find it nearly 
> impossible to try NOT to hear what you heard, and so not be  able to give a 
> fresh perspecive to help your research methods.
